author: Bob Seidenberg
title: Evanston considers partnership with Northwestern student on cyclist signage program Evanston Review
text:
City officials are showing interest in teaming up with a Northwestern University student on a pilot program that promotes the use of hand signals as a way to create greater communication between cyclists and motorists.
Members of the city's Transportation and Parking Committee backed a staff recommendation last month that the city work with Charles Tokowitz, a Northwestern University student, on the pilot program. The proposal next goes to the full City Council.
"There's a lot of language that exists already," Tokowitz told the committee, "but not a lot of people know how to use it."
Tokowitz, on behalf of Design for America (DFA) — an award-winning nationwide network of interdisciplinary student teams and community members — approached officials earlier in the year with the group's idea.

... (Daniel I. Dorfman) Knowing that bicycle safety is an important issue in Evanston, the students proposed a pilot program to enhance communication.
The program would test the use of custom road signage that displays to cyclists and automotive drivers the cycling hand signals, Tokowitz said, bringing a sample sign to the committee's September meeting.
Tokowitz told the committee that the student group's research indicates that miscommunication between cyclists and automobile drivers at intersections result in collisions.
He said research by his group of 100 cyclists in Chicago and Evanston showed as many as half of the cyclists in some cases failed to use the cycling hand signals to convey their intentions at intersections.
"Automobile drivers who rarely cycle are even less likely to know what these signals mean," he said in his presentation.
One computer rendering of one of the group's signs shows a cyclist with hands in different positions, denoting left and right turns, along with a hand gesture, indicating the cyclist was slowing down.
City officials are definitely interested in teaming with students on the project, Ylda Capriccioso, the city's bike programs coordinator, told the committee.

(Bob Seidenberg) Since the passage of a bike plan update earlier in the year, she said, city staff has been using numerous education and outreach techniques to improve road etiquette, she said.
"The pilot is a simple and unique idea that would support the city's efforts and provide valuable information about effective ways to communicate to the community," she said in a memo to the committee.
To coordinate, she said, staff would need to determine the best locations along one route near campus, where a temporary sign could located.
Costs associated with the program would run less than $200 for the sheet metal to print the signs, she said.
